Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of credibility assessment in refugee claim
Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in dates, locations, family situations, and late disclosure of sexual abuse
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish a credible basis for persecution
Credibility_Factor: Significant changes in narrative, including addition of sexual abuse by brother-in-law
Legal_Rule: Credibility and plausibility findings are central to RPD's role as fact-finder
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on gender-related grounds, including sexual abuse
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to lack of credibility
Key_Evidence_Considered: Applicant's testimony, inconsistencies in narrative, psychological explanations for discrepancies
Legal_Rule_Source: IRPA, case law on reasonableness and credibility
Defendant_Response: RPD emphasized internal inconsistencies and implausibility
Evidence_Type: Testimonial evidence, narrative consistency, expert psychological reports
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review setting aside RPD decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RPD decision and referral back for re-determination
Resolution_Mechanism: Judicial review under Section 72 of IRPA
Legal_Provision: Section 96, 97 IRPA â€“ Basis for refugee protection
